segment.source: Network security Allow Local System to use computer identity for NTLM (Windows 10)
segment.target: Network security Allow Local System to use computer identity for NTLM (Windows 10)

segment.source: Describes the location, values, policy management, and security considerations for the Network security Allow Local System to use computer identity for NTLM security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the location, values, policy management, and security considerations for the Network security Allow Local System to use computer identity for NTLM security policy setting.

segment.source: Network security: Allow Local System to use computer identity for NTLM
segment.target: Network security: Allow Local System to use computer identity for NTLM

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Describes the location, values, policy management, and security considerations for the Network security: Allow Local System to use computer identity for NTLM security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the location, values, policy management, and security considerations for the Network security: Allow Local System to use computer identity for NTLM security policy setting.

segment.source: Reference
segment.target: Reference

segment.source: When services connect to devices that are running versions of the Windows operating system earlier than Windows Vista or Windows Server 2008, services that run as Local System and use SPNEGO (Negotiate) that revert to NTLM will authenticate anonymously.
segment.target: When services connect to devices that are running versions of the Windows operating system earlier than Windows Vista or Windows Server 2008, services that run as Local System and use SPNEGO (Negotiate) that revert to NTLM will authenticate anonymously.

segment.source: In Windows Server 2008 R2 and Windows 7 and later, if a service connects to a computer running Windows Server 2008 or Windows Vista, the system service uses the computer identity.
segment.target: In Windows Server 2008 R2 and Windows 7 and later, if a service connects to a computer running Windows Server 2008 or Windows Vista, the system service uses the computer identity.

segment.source: When a service connects with the device identity, signing and encryption are supported to provide data protection.
segment.target: When a service connects with the device identity, signing and encryption are supported to provide data protection.

segment.source: (When a service connects anonymously, a system-generated session key is created, which provides no protection, but it allows applications to sign and encrypt data without errors.
segment.target: (When a service connects anonymously, a system-generated session key is created, which provides no protection, but it allows applications to sign and encrypt data without errors.

segment.source: Anonymous authentication uses a NULL session, which is a session with a server in which no user authentication is performed; and therefore, anonymous access is allowed.)
segment.target: Anonymous authentication uses a NULL session, which is a session with a server in which no user authentication is performed; and therefore, anonymous access is allowed.)

segment.source: Possible values
segment.target: Possible values

segment.source: Setting
segment.target: Setting

segment.source: Windows Server 2008 and Windows Vista
segment.target: Windows Server 2008 and Windows Vista

segment.source: At least Windows Server 2008 R2 and Windows 7
segment.target: At least Windows Server 2008 R2 and Windows 7

segment.source: Enabled
segment.target: Enabled

segment.source: Services running as Local System that use Negotiate will use the computer identity.
segment.target: Services running as Local System that use Negotiate will use the computer identity.

segment.source: This might cause some authentication requests between Windows operating systems to fail and log an error.
segment.target: This might cause some authentication requests between Windows operating systems to fail and log an error.

segment.source: Services running as Local System that use Negotiate will use the computer identity.
segment.target: Services running as Local System that use Negotiate will use the computer identity.

segment.source: This is the default behavior.
segment.target: This is the default behavior.

segment.source: Disabled
segment.target: Disabled

segment.source: Services running as Local System that use Negotiate when reverting to NTLM authentication will authenticate anonymously.
segment.target: Services running as Local System that use Negotiate when reverting to NTLM authentication will authenticate anonymously.

segment.source: This is the default behavior.
segment.target: This is the default behavior.

segment.source: Services running as Local System that use Negotiate when reverting to NTLM authentication will authenticate anonymously.
segment.target: Services running as Local System that use Negotiate when reverting to NTLM authentication will authenticate anonymously.

segment.source: Neither
segment.target: Neither

segment.source: Services running as Local System that use Negotiate when reverting to NTLM authentication will authenticate anonymously.
segment.target: Services running as Local System that use Negotiate when reverting to NTLM authentication will authenticate anonymously.

segment.source: Services running as Local System that use Negotiate will use the computer identity.
segment.target: Services running as Local System that use Negotiate will use the computer identity.

segment.source: This might cause some authentication requests between Windows operating systems to fail and log an error.
segment.target: This might cause some authentication requests between Windows operating systems to fail and log an error.

segment.source: Policy management
segment.target: Policy management

segment.source: This section describes features and tools that are available to help you manage this policy.
segment.target: This section describes features and tools that are available to help you manage this policy.

segment.source: Restart requirement
segment.target: Restart requirement

segment.source: None.
segment.target: None.

segment.source: Changes to this policy become effective without a device restart when they are saved locally or distributed through Group Policy.
segment.target: Changes to this policy become effective without a device restart when they are saved locally or distributed through Group Policy.

segment.source: Policy conflict considerations
segment.target: Policy conflict considerations

segment.source: The policy Network security: Allow LocalSystem NULL session fallback, if enabled, will allow NTLM or Kerberos authentication to be used when a system service attempts authentication.
segment.target: The policy Network security: Allow LocalSystem NULL session fallback, if enabled, will allow NTLM or Kerberos authentication to be used when a system service attempts authentication.

segment.source: This will increase the success of interoperability at the expense of security.
segment.target: This will increase the success of interoperability at the expense of security.

segment.source: The anonymous authentication behavior is different for Windows Server 2008 and Windows Vista than later versions of Windows.
segment.target: The anonymous authentication behavior is different for Windows Server 2008 and Windows Vista than later versions of Windows.

segment.source: Configuring and applying this policy setting on those systems might not produce the same results.
segment.target: Configuring and applying this policy setting on those systems might not produce the same results.

segment.source: Group Policy
segment.target: Group Policy

segment.source: This policy setting can be configured by using the Group Policy Management Console (GPMC) to be distributed through Group Policy Objects (GPOs).
segment.target: This policy setting can be configured by using the Group Policy Management Console (GPMC) to be distributed through Group Policy Objects (GPOs).

segment.source: If this policy is not contained in a distributed GPO, this policy can be configured on the local computer by using the Local Security Policy snap-in.
segment.target: If this policy is not contained in a distributed GPO, this policy can be configured on the local computer by using the Local Security Policy snap-in.

segment.source: Security considerations
segment.target: Security considerations

segment.source: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.
segment.target: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.

segment.source: Vulnerability
segment.target: Vulnerability

segment.source: When a service connects to computers running versions of Windows earlier than Windows Vista or Windows Server 2008, services that run as Local System and use SPNEGO (Negotiate) that revert to NTLM will use NULL session.
segment.target: When a service connects to computers running versions of Windows earlier than Windows Vista or Windows Server 2008, services that run as Local System and use SPNEGO (Negotiate) that revert to NTLM will use NULL session.

segment.source: In Windows Server 2008 R2 and Windows 7 and later, if a service connects to a computer running Windows Server 2008 or Windows Vista, the system service uses the computer identity.
segment.target: In Windows Server 2008 R2 and Windows 7 and later, if a service connects to a computer running Windows Server 2008 or Windows Vista, the system service uses the computer identity.

segment.source: When a service connects with the computer identity, signing and encryption are supported to provide data protection.
segment.target: When a service connects with the computer identity, signing and encryption are supported to provide data protection.

segment.source: When a service connects with a NULL session, a system-generated session key is created, which provides no protection, but it allows applications to sign and encrypt data without errors.
segment.target: When a service connects with a NULL session, a system-generated session key is created, which provides no protection, but it allows applications to sign and encrypt data without errors.

segment.source: Countermeasure
segment.target: Countermeasure

segment.source: You can configure the Network security: Allow Local System to use computer identity for NTLM security policy setting to allow Local System services that use Negotiate to use the computer identity when reverting to NTLM authentication.
segment.target: You can configure the Network security: Allow Local System to use computer identity for NTLM security policy setting to allow Local System services that use Negotiate to use the computer identity when reverting to NTLM authentication.

segment.source: Potential impact
segment.target: Potential impact

segment.source: If you do not configure this policy setting on Windows Server 2008 and Windows Vista, services running as Local System that use the default credentials will use the NULL session and revert to NTLM authentication for Windows operating systems earlier than Windows Vista or Windows Server 2008.
segment.target: If you do not configure this policy setting on Windows Server 2008 and Windows Vista, services running as Local System that use the default credentials will use the NULL session and revert to NTLM authentication for Windows operating systems earlier than Windows Vista or Windows Server 2008.

segment.source: Beginning with Windows Server 2008 R2 and Windows 7, the system allows Local System services that use Negotiate to use the computer identity when reverting to NTLM authentication.
segment.target: Beginning with Windows Server 2008 R2 and Windows 7, the system allows Local System services that use Negotiate to use the computer identity when reverting to NTLM authentication.
